attributes.title: Exploring the link between temporal comparison and self-concept clarity

q1.value: Exploring the link between temporal comparison and self-concept clarity (Study 1)

q3.value:
I will examine how people compare their present to past selves and how doing so affects self-concept clarity, which is the extent to which our self-beliefs are clear and consistently defined (Campbell, Trapnell, Heine, Katz, & Lavallee, 1996). Why should temporal self-comparisons influence self-concept clarity? According to the “common good” phenomenon, shared traits between two individuals tend to be positive whereas unshared traits are negative (Alves, Koch, & Unkelbach, 2017). In terms of temporal self-comparisons, this would mean that similarities between the past and present selves will be positive and differences between the two would be negative.  

These outcomes may influence the level of self-concept clarity individuals experience. If a comparison brings to mind negative self-attributes, self-concept clarity may be lower as a result because negative attributes are relatively unstable over time, inconsistent with each other (and with most other self attributes), and not considered the “core” of who a person feels she is. On the other hand, when a temporal comparison brings to mind positive self-attributes, the opposite pattern should emerge; positive attributes are stable over time, more consistent with each other and with most other self attributes, and are considered the “core” of who a person feels she is. I am particularly interested in how the present self-clarity changes when the comparison is to the past. This is yet an unexplored idea in social psychological research.

q4.value:
H1: Replicate past findings: past differences will be rated most negative, followed by present differences. Past and present similarities will be rated most positive and not different from one another. 
H2: Focusing on similarities (in both target conditions) leads to greater self-concept clarity as similarities are more consistent with each other, more stable, and positive.
H2.1: Focusing on past differences leads to greater self-concept clarity because differences are more diagnostic. Thinking about negative attributes that I have lost might bring to mind stability of positive attributes, and clearly define the present self in terms how it is unique.
H2.2: Focusing on present differences leads to greater self-concept clarity because differences are more diagnostic. Thinking about new features of the present self will bring to mind a clear and unique self concept (again, defining the present self based on how it is unique).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: In the basic paradigm, participants will compare themselves over time (e.g., their past to their present) by either focusing on similarities or differences. Following each 5-year comparison, participants will rate their level of self-concept clarity. This is a 2x2 between-subjects experimental design.

q9.value: Since this study is a 2x2 experimental design, participants will be randomly assigned to one of the four possible target/comparison conditions (past/present + similarities/differences).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Cloud Research (Amazon MTurk). Participants will be paid $1.00 for completing this study, which will take about 5-7 minutes. Participants must be at least 18 years old and will be from the USA.

q13.value: Our target sample is 265 participants. We will attempt to recruit a total 280, to account for any exclusions that may be necessary.

q14.value: We used to software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain  90% power to detect a small to medium effect size of Cohens f = 0.22 at the standard 0.05 alpha error rate.

question.value: Participants will receive one of the four possible conditions regarding a 5-year temporal comparison by focusing on either the past or the present and similarities or differences. Thus, both Target (past vs. present) and Comparison (similarity vs. difference) will be manipulated between-subjects.

Participants are asked to list 4 attributes of the target self, and are then shown the four attributes they had written previously. They are then instructed to rate the valence of each one on a 7-point scale (1 = extremely negative, 7 = extremely positive). We will also measure the level of present self-concept clarity (Campbell et al., 1996). Participants will rate their self concept clarity (e.g., "My beliefs about myself often conflict with one another") using a 5-point scale (1=strongly disagree; 5=strongly agree). See materials for full scale. Participants also complete a manipulation check and demographics.

We will use a 2-way between-subjects ANOVA to analyze the main effects and interaction (target, comparison, target x comparison) on target ratings and self-concept clarity. We will also supplement the NHST with Bayes Factors where appropriate.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA test suggests that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. We will report Bayes factors to supplement NHST when appropriate.

q22.value: We will examine participants’ writing samples (e.g., their trait lists) and consider excluding participants who did not provide adequate data or did not follow instructions (e.g., writing nonsense words). We will be fully transparent in those decisions and provide information on those decisions in a supplement if needed. We will also examine participants’ responses to the primary DVs (trait ratings, self-concept clarity) and flag those who show evidence of random reporting (Dupuis, Meier, Cuneo, 2018).

q23.value: We will attempt to avoid missingness by encouraging participants to complete all items. If data is partially complete, means will be calculated on the complete data. For data that is more than 80% missing, the participant will be excluded from analysis.

q24.value: We may choose to code participants' traits for valence and other content (e.g., using LIWC) and analyze these data using the plan specified in the analysis section. We may also consider looking at demographics (e.g., age) as moderators or covariates.

attributes.title: Fear motives, intusive thoughts, volitional strength and well-being among managers.

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value:
Fear motives, intusive thoughts, volitional strength and well-being among managers.

This study aims at 1) investigating if fear motive depletes volitional strength through intrusive thoughts, 2) if the these processes mediate the well-established relationship between fear motive and impaired personal well-being and 3) if this mediational effect holds true longitudinally.

sample.value:
As the study was already conducted and the data were already collected, this section is not appropriate for our studies. 

The sample of the first study composes of 100 participants (managers) and the sample of the second study composes of 80 participants (managers).

analyses.value:
For the first study, we will conduct a mediational analysis to see if intrusive thoughts mediate the relationship between fear motive and volitional strength using either The PROCESS Macro for SPSS or lavaan package for R. 

For the second study, a path analysis using lavaan package in R will be conducted. Fear motive will be entered as exogenous variable and the presumed mediators (intrusions and volitional strength) and the dependent variables (SWB), measured at times 1 and 2, as endogenous variables.

outliers.value:
No outlier analyses will be conducted. 

As for the exclusion, those participants who did not finish answering all of the questionnaires will be excluded from the study.

dependent.value:
As we conducted two studies (one investigating if unwanted intrusions mediate the relationship between fear motives and volitional strength, and other investigating if this mediation lead to impaired well-being), we had two main dependent variables. 

1- Volitional Strength: it was measured through the Volitional Components Inventory (VCI; Kuhl & Fuhrmann, 1998). For subscales from the VCI were used to measure volitional strength, which are motivation control, emotion control, attention control, and decision control. Each subscale consisted of six items and the participants were asked to rate each item on 7-point likert scale (from 1 = very rarely to 7 = very often). The subscales were aggregated into a composite measure of volitional strength (23 items, Cronbach's Alpha = .92). 

2- Subjective well-being (SWB):  Positive and negative affect were measured using the 16 item instrument introduced by Brunstein, Lautenschlager, Nawroth, Pöhlmann, and Schultheiss (1995). Brunstein (1993) and Lucas et al. (1996) used similar procedures. Participants read, “How often have you recently experienced the following moods…” and then rated emotional adjectives on seven-point scales from never (1) to very frequently (7). Positive affect was assessed using an aggregated measure of the elated mood (happy, joyful, pleased, and excellent) and the activation subscale (energetic, active, cheery, and vigorous). Negative affect was assessed using a composite measure of the depressed mood (dejected, distressed, sad, and depressed) and the energy deficit subscale (limp, unmotivated, sluggish, and inert).

conditions.value: There are no conditions in this study as it was not an experimental one.

hypothesis.value:
1- Does fear motive lead to unwanted intrusions which require and ultimately deplete volitional strength? 
2- Do these processes (fear motive leading to unwanted intrusion and intrusion in turn, depleting volitional strength) mediate the well-established relation between fear motives and impaired personal well-being ?

study_type_other.value: Field studies in the form of surveys (surveys distributed to managers).

attributes.title: CFTR modulators in triple combination in patients with cystic fibrosis
attributes.description: Clinical efficacy of CFTR modulators in triple combination in patients with cystic fibrosis and one or two Phe508del alleles: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

q1.value: CFTR modulators in triple combination in patients with cystic fibrosis

q2.value: José Luis Ortiz, Julia Pérez, Rafael Badenes, Julio Cortijo, Esteban Morcillo

q3.value: We will study the efficacy of elexacaftor–tezacaftor-ivacaftor or VX-659–tezacaftor-ivacaftor in triple combinations versus double combinations of tezacaftor-ivacaftor or lumacaftor-ivacaftor or placebo on outcomes such as forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1), sweat chloride concentration and Cystic-Fibrosis Questionnaire-Revised (CFQ-R) in patients with cystic fibrosis who are homozygous  and heterozygous for the F508del mutation. We will carry out a systematic review and treatment comparison by meta-analysis of the clinical variables named above to evaluate the efficacy of the different combinations of CFTR modulators.

q4.value: Triple-combination therapy with CFTR modulators will provide greater efficacy in the F508Del patient population.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study is a systematic review and meta-analysis.

q9.value: We will include randomised controlled and non-randomized clinical trials to assess the beneficial effects of the treatments.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: We will include randomised controlled and non-randomized clinical trials to assess the beneficial effects of the treatments. We will not restrict studies according to study duration or study setting; however, we will limit our review to those that include the specified populations (patients 12 years of age or older with cystic fibrosis and one or two Phe508del alleles) and capture the outcomes of interest.

q13.value: In this systematic review and meta-analysis we will analyze the number of patients included in the different clinical trials.

question.value:
Primary outcome(s)
Absolute change in the percentage of predicted FEV1. Clinical efficacy was evaluated on the basis of the change in force expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) from baseline.
Secondary outcomes:
Secondary outcomes of interest include:
•	Sweat chloride concentration: Change from baseline.
•	Disease-specific quality of life: specifically, as measured with the Cystic Fibrosis Questionnaire-Revised (CFQ R).
A meta-analysis will be performed to obtain comparisons between the different combinations of CFTR modulators in patients with cystic fibrosis and one or two Phe508del alleles.

summary.value: First registration.  Contains all elements relevant for publication.  Please see the READ.me file in in the github data for further information about this project..

attributes.title: Morality & Sunglasses
attributes.description: Examining the impact of wearing sunglasses on moral decision making

q1.value: Experimental investigation of the impact of wearing sunglasses on lying behaviour

q3.value:
In a seminal paper by Zhong, Bohns and Gino (2010), the authors observed that participants who were placed in a room with slightly dimmed lighting cheated more than participants in a well-lit room. They speculated that the experience of darkness incuded increased feelings of anonymity that increased morally questionnable behaviours. To support their hypothesis, they conducted a series of additional studies in which participants were asked to wear or not sunglasses while playing a modified version of the dictator game. They found that participants wearing sunglasses were transferring lower amounts of money than those wearing clear glasses. They suggested that sunglasses increased feelings of anonymity which in turns exerted participants to behave more dishonestly. 
However we find some limitations to their study that may prevent them from making such a conclusion: 1) they used a modified version of the Dictator Game that has been developed to assess altruism and not dishonest behaviour; 2) recent studies suggested the Dictator Game to be subject to severe experimental demand affects and thus questionning the results from such games (Zizzo, 2010); 3) their sample size may be too small to offer robust conclusions. 
We thus aim at examining the impact of wearing sunglasses on moral decision making. We aim at investigating whether participants wearing sunglasses behave more dishonestly than those wearing no sunglasses.
To fulfill our purpose we plan to conduct two studies:
In a first study, we aim at replicating Zhong et al. (2010) results based on the dictator game. thus we will ask a group of participants to play as dictator wearing sunglasses and confront their observations with another group of participants playing as dictators but wearing no sunglasses.
In a second study, we will use a standard paradigm in dishonesty (the dice-under-cup paradigm) and compare the behaviours from participants wearing sunglasses with those of participants wearing no sunglasses.

q4.value:
We state the following hypotheses:
1) Dictators wearing sunglasses transfer lower amounts to recipients than those wearing no sunglasses because of increased feelings of anonymity.
2) Participants wearing sunglasses lie more than participants wearing no sunglasses because of increased feelings of anonymity.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value:
Study 1: 
Standard Dictator Game: Participants are asked to play as a dictator in standard dictator game. they are informed that they have a 10€ endowment and they can transfer any amount they want to a recipient. Some participants will be asked to wear sunglasses while others no. 
Study 2: 
Standard Dice-under-cup paradigm: participants are asked to roll a die placed inside an opaque cup and there is a peep-hole lid on the top. This variation allows players to look at the dice readings through the peep-hole and, actually, only players per se can see the real readings. Participants are paid according to the number they report and not to they number they actually got. Some participants will be wearing sunglasses whereas others no. 

in both studies, we will measure perceived anonymity by asking them a series of questions at the end of the experiment by using the same questions as Zhong, Bohns & Gino (2010)

q9.value: Studies will be based on laboratory experiments and participants will be randomly allocated to conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: We will not use existing data.

question.value: Participants registered in the pool of participants. Excluding participants who already participated to an experiment based on altruism (study 1) or dishonesty (study 2)

q13.value:
In Study 1, participants will participate to a standard dictator game. We will compare means from independent samples (Mann Whitney Tests). Assuming an effect size of .5 (medium), an type 1 error of .05 and a power of .95, we will need to collect 105 observations in each condition (wearing sunglasses vs No Sunglasses).
In Study 2, participants will participate to a standard dice-under-cup paradigm. We set 
N such that the probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis of no lying when the null hypothesis is false is at least 80%. Namely, N is defined such that if we observe 30% of participants reporting a 6, the binomial test has a power of more than 80% to reject the null hypothesis of no lying. Using p = .167 (predicted) and p = .3 (observed), N (71)  leads to a power of .8024

q15.value: We will stop collecting data as soon as we will have the required number of independent observations.

question.value:
In both studies, we will manipulate whether participants will wear or no sunglasses while participating to the experiment. Sunglasses will be identical for all participants. 
In Study 1, the observable variable will be the transfer (amount of money sent to the recipient) by participants. In study 2, the observable variable will be the number (and so payoff) reported by the participant.

In study 1; Participants (wearing or not wearing sunglasses) will have a 10€ endowment and can choose to send any fraction of that endowment to a recipient. The amount sent then ranges from 0 to 10 € (integer amounts only).
In study 2; Participants (wearing or not wearing sunglasses) will roll a six face die and have to report the number obtained as a payoff. The reported number than can range from 1 to 6.
In both studies, feelings of anonymity will be assessed through a series of 5 questions listed at the end of the studies.

At the end of each study, participants are asked to answer a list of 5 questions using a scale from 1 (Strongly Disagree) to 7 (Strongly Agree). Two variables must be reversed (variable 1 and 5). An index of Feelings of Anonymity is created by averaging the scores.
Only non-parametric statistics: mann whitney tests, kruskal-wallis tests, chi-square tests.

q20.value: In study 1, we will compute the proportion of fair transfers (transfers = 5), low transfers (transfers <5) and high transfers (transfers >5) among participants wearing and not wearing sunglasses

q21.value: Using Two tailed tests and defining a significance threshold of p = .05.

registration_responses.q1: Experimental investigation of the impact of wearing sunglasses on lying behaviour
registration_responses.q3:
In a seminal paper by Zhong, Bohns and Gino (2010), the authors observed that participants who were placed in a room with slightly dimmed lighting cheated more than participants in a well-lit room. They speculated that the experience of darkness incuded increased feelings of anonymity that increased morally questionnable behaviours. To support their hypothesis, they conducted a series of additional studies in which participants were asked to wear or not sunglasses while playing a modified version of the dictator game. They found that participants wearing sunglasses were transferring lower amounts of money than those wearing clear glasses. They suggested that sunglasses increased feelings of anonymity which in turns exerted participants to behave more dishonestly. 
However we find some limitations to their study that may prevent them from making such a conclusion: 1) they used a modified version of the Dictator Game that has been developed to assess altruism and not dishonest behaviour; 2) recent studies suggested the Dictator Game to be subject to severe experimental demand affects and thus questionning the results from such games (Zizzo, 2010); 3) their sample size may be too small to offer robust conclusions. 
We thus aim at examining the impact of wearing sunglasses on moral decision making. We aim at investigating whether participants wearing sunglasses behave more dishonestly than those wearing no sunglasses.
To fulfill our purpose we plan to conduct two studies:
In a first study, we aim at replicating Zhong et al. (2010) results based on the dictator game. thus we will ask a group of participants to play as dictator wearing sunglasses and confront their observations with another group of participants playing as dictators but wearing no sunglasses.
In a second study, we will use a standard paradigm in dishonesty (the dice-under-cup paradigm) and compare the behaviours from participants wearing sunglasses with those of participants wearing no sunglasses.
registration_responses.q4:
We state the following hypotheses:
1) Dictators wearing sunglasses transfer lower amounts to recipients than those wearing no sunglasses because of increased feelings of anonymity.
2) Participants wearing sunglasses lie more than participants wearing no sunglasses because of increased feelings of anonymity.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
registration_responses.q9: Studies will be based on laboratory experiments and participants will be randomly allocated to conditions.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: We will not use existing data.
registration_responses.q13:
In Study 1, participants will participate to a standard dictator game. We will compare means from independent samples (Mann Whitney Tests). Assuming an effect size of .5 (medium), an type 1 error of .05 and a power of .95, we will need to collect 105 observations in each condition (wearing sunglasses vs No Sunglasses).
In Study 2, participants will participate to a standard dice-under-cup paradigm. We set 
N such that the probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis of no lying when the null hypothesis is false is at least 80%. Namely, N is defined such that if we observe 30% of participants reporting a 6, the binomial test has a power of more than 80% to reject the null hypothesis of no lying. Using p = .167 (predicted) and p = .3 (observed), N (71)  leads to a power of .8024
registration_responses.q15: We will stop collecting data as soon as we will have the required number of independent observations.
registration_responses.q20: In study 1, we will compute the proportion of fair transfers (transfers = 5), low transfers (transfers <5) and high transfers (transfers >5) among participants wearing and not wearing sunglasses
registration_responses.q21: Using Two tailed tests and defining a significance threshold of p = .05.
registration_responses.q8.question:
Study 1: 
Standard Dictator Game: Participants are asked to play as a dictator in standard dictator game. they are informed that they have a 10€ endowment and they can transfer any amount they want to a recipient. Some participants will be asked to wear sunglasses while others no. 
Study 2: 
Standard Dice-under-cup paradigm: participants are asked to roll a die placed inside an opaque cup and there is a peep-hole lid on the top. This variation allows players to look at the dice readings through the peep-hole and, actually, only players per se can see the real readings. Participants are paid according to the number they report and not to they number they actually got. Some participants will be wearing sunglasses whereas others no. 

in both studies, we will measure perceived anonymity by asking them a series of questions at the end of the experiment by using the same questions as Zhong, Bohns & Gino (2010)
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants registered in the pool of participants. Excluding participants who already participated to an experiment based on altruism (study 1) or dishonesty (study 2)
registration_responses.q16.question:
In both studies, we will manipulate whether participants will wear or no sunglasses while participating to the experiment. Sunglasses will be identical for all participants. 
In Study 1, the observable variable will be the transfer (amount of money sent to the recipient) by participants. In study 2, the observable variable will be the number (and so payoff) reported by the participant.
registration_responses.q17.question:
In study 1; Participants (wearing or not wearing sunglasses) will have a 10€ endowment and can choose to send any fraction of that endowment to a recipient. The amount sent then ranges from 0 to 10 € (integer amounts only).
In study 2; Participants (wearing or not wearing sunglasses) will roll a six face die and have to report the number obtained as a payoff. The reported number than can range from 1 to 6.
In both studies, feelings of anonymity will be assessed through a series of 5 questions listed at the end of the studies.
registration_responses.q18.question: At the end of each study, participants are asked to answer a list of 5 questions using a scale from 1 (Strongly Disagree) to 7 (Strongly Agree). Two variables must be reversed (variable 1 and 5). An index of Feelings of Anonymity is created by averaging the scores.
registration_responses.q19.question: Only non-parametric statistics: mann whitney tests, kruskal-wallis tests, chi-square tests.

attributes.title: Age and Political Identification
attributes.description: How does age effect political identification
